he: וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה סָבַר יָדַיִם שֶׁאֵין מוֹכִיחוֹת לָא הָוְיָין יָדַיִם וְטַעְמָא דִּכְתַב לַהּ וְדֵן דְּמוֹכְחָא מִילְּתָא דִּבְהַאי גִּיטָּא קָא מְגָרֵשׁ לַהּ אֲבָל לָא כְּתַב לָהּ וְדֵן אָמְרִי בְּדִיבּוּרָא גָּרְשַׁהּ וּשְׁטָרָא רְאָיָה בְּעָלְמָא הוּא
text: And Rabbi Yehuda holds that ambiguous intimations are not valid intimations, and therefore the reason that the bill of divorce is valid is that he writes for her: And this that you shall have from me is a scroll of divorce and a letter of leave, so it is evident that he is divorcing her with this bill of divorce. But if he does not write for her: And this that you shall have from me is a scroll of divorce and a letter of leave, people will say that he is divorcing her orally, and will mistakenly assume that the husband’s statement to her when he hands her the bill of divorce is what causes the divorce to take effect, and that the document is merely evidence of the divorce, rather than the divorce itself.
